content.description:
“The West did not, as is widely believed, win the Cold War through geopolitical containment and military deterrence. Nor was the Cold War won by the Reagan military buildup and the Reagan Doctrine, as some have suggested. Instead, ‘victory’ for the West came when a new generation of Soviet leaders realized how badly their system at home and their policies abroad had failed. What containment did was to successfully stalemate Moscow’s attempts to advance Soviet hegemony. Over four decades it performed the historic function of keeping Soviet power in check until the internal seeds of destruction within the Soviet Union and its empire could mature. At that point, however, it was Gorbachev who brought the Cold War to an end. . . .
Although Gorbachev remained a Socialist, and in his own terms perhaps even a Marxist-Leninist, . . . he renounced the idea of inevitable world conflict. His avowed acceptance of the interdependence of the world, of the priority of all-human values over class values, . . . marked a revolutionary ideological change.”
Raymond Garthoff, American diplomat, “Why Did the Cold War End?” journal article, 1992
content.question: Which of the following would most directly challenge the author’s claim that Gorbachev may have remained a committed Marxist?

choices.label: Gorbachev implemented a Five-Year Plan to direct Soviet economic development.
Gorbachev implemented free-market reforms as part of the perestroika program.
Gorbachev held several positions of increasing power and responsibility in Soviet government before becoming its leader.
Gorbachev allowed public criticism of himself and other Soviet officials.

content.answer: Gorbachev implemented free-market reforms as part of the perestroika program.
